questions.question_text: Which is a key benefit of using Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Autonomous Data Warehouse?

discussion.content: B is correct

Selected Answer: B
Correct Answer: B

Yes! According to the given link: http://www.oracle.com/us/products/database/autonomous-dw-cloud-ipaper-3938921.pdf

<<Oracle Autonomous Data Warehouse uses applied
machine learning to self-tune and automatically
optimizes performance while the database is running.>>
B. Auto scale benefit
@Lakoth, One doesn't need to apply the patch, AD is self patching

B is correct, but why is C not also correct?: 
"C. Apply database patches as they become available. "

comments.content: Not C because that is not only for autonomous.

discussion.content: B. Scale both CPU and Storage without downtime.

choices.C: Apply database patches as they become available.
choices.B: Scale both CPU and Storage without downtime.
choices.A: Maintain root-level access to the underlying operating system.

discussion.content: I think ,Subscribe to the desired region is the correct answer

Answer is B.
To create an instance in another region, perform these preliminary steps:
1. Extend your subscription to another region.
2. Federate Oracle Identity Cloud Service (IDCS) from the new region with Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI).
https://docs.oracle.com/en/cloud/paas/content-cloud/administer/create-instance-oracle-cloud-console.html#GUID-A617736E-EC2B-4720-ABD7-8ADCDCBE0D59

Selected Answer: B
To create resources in a different region, you need to subscribe to the new region first.

B is correct Answer
Nobody thought it might be D eh? My free account does not even allow me to subscribe to additional region so a new admin would face similar issue LOL

Actually A & B can be correct. If the Tenancy already had the desired Region subscribe to then you will be able to login, navigate to the Region and create resources. However if the Region desired has not been subscribe to he would need to 1st subscribe to the Region.
B is correct. I selected it. got 100%

A is the right answer, you need to extend your subscription If you already have an existing subscription. The key here is "as an administrator for the first time" For the first time, which means no existing region or anything. Hence Its option A. If its not the first time or already there is an existing subscription, than yes answer will be B.

comments.content:
https://docs.oracle.com/en/cloud/get-started/subscriptions-cloud/mmocs/extending-your-subscription-another-data-region.html

questions.question_text:
A new customer has logged into Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) as an administrator for the first time. The admin would like to deploy infrastructure into a region other than their home region.
What is the first step they must take in order to accomplish this task?

discussion.content: A is correct

Selected Answer: A
A is the correct choice.

A is correct. see this 
https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Billing/Tasks/create-alert-rule.htm

Selected Answer: A
That's what the dude in the training vid said, anyway.

Selected Answer: A
A. Budgets

A: A budget can be used to set soft limits on your Oracle Cloud Infrastructure spending. You can set alerts on your budget to let you know when you might exceed your budget, and you can view all of your budgets and spending from one single place in the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure console.

You can define email alerts that get sent out for your budget. You can send a customized email message body with these alerts. Alerts are evaluated every hour in most regions.

https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Billing/Concepts/budgetsoverview.htm
A - Budgets
A is correct
A. For budget alerts

d events:
Budgets are a tool in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure that help you track ... Now, you can also trigger events on budgets, using the Events service

questions.question_text: Which Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) service can send you an alert when you might exceed your spending threshold?

A customer is looking to migrate their old database backups from their on-premises data center to Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI).
Which OCI service is the most cost-effective?

discussion.content: answer A
ans is A. archive storage is 10x cheaper for this use
Archive is more cost-effective than other in the option

Selected Answer: A
A (Archive Storage) seems the most cost effective for 'old' DB backups
Ans is A as it says OLD DB backup hence A is correct

Selected Answer: A
As it's mentioned cost-effective, it should be archive
C. Object Storage.

Selected Answer: A
A. Archive Storage
A is the correct answer. The word cost effective means cheapest option which will be Archive storage.

Selected Answer: A
What made-head would use hot storage? Even if the retention on cold storage put you off, the shorter retention on infrequent access (cool) would be better than hot.

Selected Answer: A
A. Archive Storage

Selected Answer: A
Is correct A

Selected Answer: A
A- correct

Selected Answer: A
In terms of cost, File Storage > Block Volume > Object Storage

Within Object Storage, Archive is the cheapest.
(Storage cost: Standard>Infrequent Access>Archive)
(retrieval access/cost: Archive>Infrequent Access>Standard)

Answer is A-Archive Storage.

Selected Answer: A
archive storage is cheaper
Normally it should be answer A
A is correct
Answer should be A
Answer A, most cost effective. The uses cases for Archive Storage: Long term archival and backups (Oracle DB backups)

Use Archive Storage for data to which you seldom or rarely access, but that must be retained and preserved for long periods of time. The cost efficiency of the Archive Storage offsets the long lead time required to access the data.
Use Object Storage for data to which you need fast, immediate, and frequent access. Data accessibility and performance justifies a higher price to store data in the Object Storage. For more information, see Overview of Object Storage. Source kink is provided in Anubhav244's comment : https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Archive/Concepts/archivestorageoverview.htm

Ans should be 'A'. Cost Effective
Check : https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Archive/Concepts/archivestorageoverview.htm
Answer is A
A. The cheapest option
A - Archive Storage. It is less expensive and would fit the requirement of storing "old" backups (customer will not need immediate access to the backup files)
Old database backups means without any retention policy hence correct answer could be C !! Cold Storage will be cost effective but will have retention policy attached with it.
A is the good answer as it cost much less then others solution and this is the key point of the question
Archive storage is most cost effective so answer is A
C. Object storage (standard)
Agreed that it is A, it is just to store database backupS; if used for moving database backup to cloud for data migration, it would have been C

Answer should be A. It asks for the most cost-effective service. With the most cost effective being Archive Storage.
Object Storage has two storage classes 1. Standard (Hot Storage) 2. Archive (Cold Storage)
D is incorrect since Standard Object Storage cost 10x more than Archive Object Storage
Answer is A. keyword "old backups" and " cost effective". this question comes up on EXAM
"migrating their old database backups", not database migration. Old, rarely accessed... Most cost Effective. I think it's A.
A is more cost effective than C
They mentioned migrate old backups from On-premises to OCI , C is correct

They mentioned migrate old backups from On-premises to OCI which means Old - Archive Storage
If they did ask to migrate environment / DB / backups which are current and future then it is Object storage
They have specifically asked for cost effective solution. So the answer s A. Archive Storage
Object storage is correct as its used by default for db backups

comments.content: I have to agree with crysis. From one side I agree that the most cost effective will be A but before using A the only supported to transfer on-premise backup is object storage. So my guess object storage is desired answer.

questions.question_text: Which three components are part of Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Identity and Access Management service? (Choose three.)

discussion.content: That is correct. A.B.G is the correct answer. Verified from https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Identity/Concepts/overview.htm#one

Selected Answer: ABG
Correct Answer: ABG
that's exact
A, B and G are the best options
ABG correct
Answer should be A, E, G - Users, Compute Instances and Policies

comments.content: I thought so too, but it's not true per https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Identity/Concepts/overview.htm#one

discussion.content: Why not D ? Roles are also part of IAM.
